text: this is melian do a small village tucked
into the force of southeastern guinea it
is home to a few dozen families it has
no electricity and no running water here
in December of 2013 a 1 year old boy
named Emil is thought to be the first
victim of the Ebola outbreak by the end
of March 11 people will have died in the
village the boy's grandmother is linked
to two people from the nearby village of
Dawa who get the disease a relative of
Mele induce midwife takes a bullet to
yet another village dhondu Pombo
it takes about 30 minutes to drive on
the dirt road from million due to the
largest town nearby deca do the Midwife
is taken to a hospital there in getcha
do a health worker also becomes ill and
is taken to mass enta soon after a
doctor dies there the doctor is buried
in cocido goo within weeks more than 60
people will have died across the region
the outbreak starts at the intersection
of three of the poorest countries in the
world the area is home to the kisi
ethnic group there are few official
border crossings from via do into the
neighboring country of Liberia but
extended families cross easily by foot
and dugout canoe
in this part of the world the few
existing clinics and hospitals often
lack running water and hand soap the
region had little familiarity with Ebola
since nearly all of the previous
outbreaks were in central Africa making
matters worse
Ebola symptoms resemble endemic diseases
in West Africa like malaria cholera and
Lassa fever by February people connected
to the first patients family are thought
to have died in Conakry and in kekaa who
Sierra Leone this indicates that the
virus probably traveled far and crossed
borders early in the outbreak but the
first confirmed cases of Ebola in Guinea
came only on March 21st days later Anna
bola case is confirmed in the capital
Conakry a city of more than one and a
half million people still reports of new
infections decline in late April a
statistical plateau that resembles the
historical outbreaks have burned out
after a few months some international
health organizations begin to relax
their operations meanwhile weak contact
tracing and local suspicion toward
foreigners and national authorities
allows the disease to spread outside the
clinics
ultimately the virus resurfaces in
Sierra Leone unconfirmed cases of people
dying in the village of Pandu with Ebola
like symptoms start as early as March
but the first confirmed case comes only
in late May in July a bola is confirmed
in Freetown the capital the patient is a
woman living in a kisi neighborhood of
the city at this point the outbreak is
surging out of control
